												Having skipped a few years from WWE 13 to WWE 2k16, i was blown away by 16 and loved it and found lots to do.  I was extremely anxious for WWE 2k17, expecting it to be an augment for 2k16, something like what WWF No Mercy was over WWF Wrestlemania 2000.The end result is immensely dissatisfying, though.  The graphics look exactly the same to me, though there may be some improvements.  Something about the way the flesh and colors look makes them all look flat and plastic.  The sort of dis-realism of the wrestlers and their expressions from 2k16 were not at all addressed here.  The game modes are all the same from 2k16, with backstage brawling and crowd brawling finally added in, but segregated so that you can't go backstage during the course of a tables match or hell in a cell match, but only if you pick Backstage Brawl.The roster list is the same ugly mess that came with 2k16.  Current superstars are mixed in with former superstars and superstar variants, seemingly without care.  Certain superstars who would have been highly publicized for inclusion (or were highly publicized for previous years) or made something unlockable or part of a "Legends" pack are just there, included in the list as if they were Aidan English or Zack Ryder, with no special labeling or being included in a separate list.The DLC for new superstars is also massively underwhelming, charging 9-10 dollars for about 7 superstars total, while not bothering to add people like the current NXT champion Bobby Roode.Ultimately what killed this game for me was the lack of attention or care to details.  Simple things that could have added a bit of zest to the experience.  WWE 2k16 had this for me in the form of the wrestler taunts; certain wrestlers' taunts had them speaking out loud.The nature of NXT now is such that it has a highly devoted, energetic fanbase, and the experience of having crowds sing along with Nakamura or Bobby Roode's entrance music can be just as awesome as a match itself.  As more NXT favorites come to the main roster (like Kevin Owens, Samoa Joe, Bayley, Charlotte Flair), their fans stick with them and bring their unique reactions and chants with them.WWE 2k17 has nothing at all like that.  The crowd is dead as any other WWE game, with the exact same monotonous crowd noise triggered at the same points of an entrance.  No one sings along to Shinsuke Nakamura's music.  There are no competing chants, no half-boos and half-cheers for the likes of John Cena or AJ Styles.  No one chants "Joe's gonna kill you" or "Asuka's gonna kill you" at the start of a Samoa Joe or Asuka match.  A superstar labelled a heel is flatly booed with generic audience boos, a face is flatly cheered with generic cheers.And the multiplayer for PC is essentially DOA.  It's exactly the same double-blind matchmaking system from WWE 2k16, where you can be waiting for hours for a matchup that will never happen while being forced to "practice" wrestle against the computer in an empty arena.Ultimately this game reeks of mediocrity, being just another cash-grab entry in a franchise that has to put out a new game yearly.  Sometimes the cycle gets broken with a whole new game (recently like WWE 12 over the Smackdown vs Raw series), but this latest entry is stuck in the middle, being little more than some tiny changes and added features over the previous entries.For a first-time buy, or for someone who hasn't played since Smackdown vs Raw, this would be an amazing WWE game, but if you've played WWE 2k16, this is more of the same, safe and predictable.

												Where to begin in this hot mess?Let us put it this way: 2k has to sincerely consider to change the development team since they seem to be unable to fix glitches and problems persistent since 2k15 and also reintroduce problems which were already fixed. Most of them are clipping issues and related to the entrance. For example: If you change the slightest bit of the entrance atttire of AJ Styles his hoodie is suddenly glued to his head. Do not dare to give any ingame superstar another jacket. While sometimes it seemingly works, on ohter occasions they will wear the belt over the jacket, which stretches it into oblivion. These issues are more prominent with custom made belts which brings me to the next glaring issue: The audio.As pointed out by several other people the annoying repeating sound at a show start is just a glaring oversight which indicates that this game was either rushed, had no Q&A or the Q&A failed miserably or was overlooked.There are numerous more issues like the recent Jerry Lawler fauxpas in the Hall of Fame DLC where a botched recording was actually left in the game. However more bothersome is the announcemet of custom titles within tag teams. Ever heard of "Jimmy Smackdown Tag Team Uso and Jey Uso"? Or "Edge Raw Tag Team Rated R Christian"? WHO IN THEIR RIGHT MIND DID NOT REALIZE THAT?These glitches even continue if one of the tag team partners is holding a singles custom title like the smackdown womens championship which was bothersome to create to say the least, since they decided to not include the RAW Womens championship as a template. "Eva Marie and Smackdown Women Emma Champion" has got to be my favourite so far. There are a lot more audio glitches but let's get going.The graphics: The first time I saw the game at GamesCom in Germany last year I was absolutely shocked. It looked worse than it's predecessor and within 5 minutes of gameplay I had multiple glitches and bugs with weird animations and clipping through an opponent. While they slightly improved on the graphics at least during entrances the glitches and bugs remained. Some of the wrestlers are on point and look great during the entrances but some others.... oh my lord. You will not recognize them since they got rid of the real life pictures. I do not know what these guys did to the developers but either they have never actually saw them, mostly women, or just straight out hate them. You think ME Andromeda has a tired face? Look at Bailey during her entrance. She looks DEAD.Gameplay: There are some minor changes in the gameplay which I actually like and put the game more towards a simulation type of game. That is not everyone's cup but that is the direction they want to go. However even here are decisions I cannot understand. For example: Try to get the cage breaker in a Hell in a Cell match. Sometimes it is plain impossible. The submission game is worse than last year with input lag that made me submit at the beginning everytime. You will get used to it but it is still absolute crap. And yes there is a second option but that seems to be even worse.Let's take a quick look at the game modes:FINALLY you can have multiple Universe modes running at the same time. More stuff to corrupt with their still bugged cloud syncingThe MyCareer mode is forgettable more so since the introduction of the Promo System. No Audio for these kills every immersion you possibly could have. And who wrote these things? A 10 year old or an actual WWE writer? Some of the answers are absolutely hilarious and do not make any sense. The system is shoddy at best and does not work correctly in Universe mode.Conclusion:Do you get your money's worth? At full prize: HELL NO! At sale prize: still NO!This is the first 2k WWE game I sincerely regret buying. My modded 2k16 was working somewhat okay and with just the additions of backstage stuff, the ring out in multiman matches, the better taunting system it would be pretty good. But they messed up so heavy AGAIN. I cannot fathom what is happening over there. I sent over 20 bug reports with videos and pictures last year and most of them are still in THIS game. Very sadly it only a 4/10 because I have hope... but it is declining fast. Oh and do not think they will fix anything about the game. They pushed out 5 TU with minor fixes and that will be it. They do not care and are probably already at 2k18.

												I'm about 10 hours into this game and I have to say that my experience, then game has run flawlessly. I have not been having the crashes and glitches that others have, but if I know the steam community, I know I can expect a ton of downvotes for saying so. Sorry.For me, the game has run very smoothly with a constant 60 fps at 1080p. The matches load quickly. I feel like the balancing has been improving every year since 2K15. I'm really good at these games, and it was impossible for the AI to beat me in previous games. Now the AI actually feels like a challenge (well, sometimes anyways). I lost my very first steel cage match, which shocked the hell out me since I have not lost one since the ps3 era. But that only made me excited to keep playing. Before, I would create a character, win the championship almost instantly and never lose it. I would get so bored. Well, not with WWE 2K17.Character customization is improved in almost every area, except one. In this game, you have more hair and clothing options than we have seen in a very long time. Clothing can now be used with both genders, which is great if you want to make a woman who looks like she can actually win a fight. The downside to this is that you no longer have the advanced morphing options that you used to have. Now you pick a base body and then mix and match pre-made parts like arms, legs, torsos, etc. No more big boob dominatrix girls for me... Oh well.When the game is running smoothly, I do recommend it. However, there is no way for me to tell you what kind of experience YOU are going to have. If the game did not work for me I would be mad too. If you are thinking of getting this game, I suggest that you do as many matches as you can within the first 2 hours. Don't waste any time with character creation. If the game is going to crash, it is likely to happen during matches. This way, if the game does not work for you, you should still be able to refund it. Believe me when I say that you can spend all day creating new wrestlers.

												Deluxe Edition reviewed - 3rd party store that was £40.FIRST IMPRESSIONS:-Much improved iteration of the last 2 games, a lot of the models have been updated and better lighting effects, higher AA options, more creation content, replay editors, will update review once had more time to mess with it, but so far first impressions are better than 2k15 and 2k16 editions.25 hours of gameplay later---------------------------------------Well a lot more time has passed and I have messed about with creation tools, played online matches, played solo career modes and have noticed subtle difference, which is easier to explain as Pros vs Cons against the 2k16 edition.Pros:-* More character ainmations* Smoother animations between actions* New taunting system is vastly improved, taunts can be performed in and around the ring, apron, and on the ropes etc. for the crowds or taunting wrestlers directly to get up etc... and the AI use it too, making it look and feel more like the TV show.* Less input lag from controller - although some of the minigames are still so-so.* Better lighting effect, noticebly more lights and smoke FXs* 8xAA supported (4xAA cap last two versions) so better quality available.* Performance of the game is still great, getting a solid 60fps in highest settings at 4k resolution, even with 8xAA it only drops by 2fps at most in a 30man Royal Rumble. (I7 3770k with gtx1080, 32gb RAM) and a lot of the cutcenes on intros are now running in 60fps (some parts are locked to 30fps still).* Better CAW system* New (text only) Promo mode added to career mode* New batch of Superstars added to roster* Simpler UI menus - stripped away all the fluff and literally just text menu system that shows everything you need to see all at once, saves a lot of time looking for sub-menus.* New basic video editor tools for making match highlights into videos for your custom character's titantron videos, although the encode seems to be glitched is a very dark output.* Loading times are vastly better, at least on my system, which helps a lot going between creator tools.* Seems they have fixed the sound problems seen in 2k15 and 2k16 where I had lost crowd sounds in custom character matches occassionally.Cons:-* Still has the dumb as♥♥♥♥♥♥console upload/download system instead of Steam Workshop, as long as still having 100 slot cap, with 20 downloads per 24 hour period limit. (seriously???)* Creation tools occasionally crash out when re-editing your characteers, causing a CTD device video driver crash - I've tried numerous drivers and nothing has fixed it, so will need dev patch.* AI is still a bit wonky on the decision making in AI matches* Some of the necklaces and gowns, cloaks etc. still suffer from clipping issues* Commentary is still quite limited, hear a lot of things repeated* Still no custom music importing* Still no custom videos for Titanwall importing* Paid DLC this time around - bit of a annoyance given it still had a 4-5 month delay in release, sorry but paid dlc should only happen if we get the game the same week as consoles, not midway into that season when 5-6 months to new build of the game.*Still no roster updates mid-season, bit annoying if they are going to DLC things up and not have a roster update to reflect heel turns and changes to intros etc. EA / FIFA do this for free... just saying.* Took out some of the old classic stars to fit in new characters, really this should ever happen, always add, never remove... I miss Honky Tonk Man etc.* Online play while on the whole seems less laggy, the matchmaking service is a utter joke... seriously needs an overhaul, thankfully I mainly play solo and mess about with custom creations, but I'd guess this a big feature to be broken for the majority of buyers. 												This game runs perfectly for me.  Zero issues.  looks good too. I am not a WWE fan.  i am a fan of video games.  i went into this thinking the over-the-top antics would translate into a very fun video game.  who wouldn't love to fly through the air landing on people like a super hero?  i am a big fan of 2K sports games, the NBA games in particular.  i am also a big fan of MMA games.  so i figured this would be a good video game for me.the gameplay is boring.  i'm judging that purely on a video game standpoint.  more than anything else i sit around watching the game play itself waiting to hit R2.  you literally can't stand up and move around until you 'reverse" a move the other guy is doing.  until then you watch the guy strut around pretending he's the best ever.  and if you miss the timing on hitting R2 to reverse the move you just continue to watch while the guy takes 5 seconds to twist your legs up into a pretzel.  i've never been into watching games play themselves.once you manage to reverse a move it's your turn.  you stand next to the guy and press a button.  then you watch to see if he counters, or if the move happens.  that's it.  you press a button and watch for 5 seconds.  then you press a button again.  wait for 5 seconds.  oh no!  this time he reversed you.  now you can't press whatever button you want you'll have to press R2 at a specific moment.  it's simply not fun gameplay.another issue i have is playing dress up with the characters.  i play career mode in all my sports games.  in this career mode you are forced to constantly change your tshirt and your moves.  this takes too much time as the menus are large and take a long time to load.  this is something i always tried to avoid in the MMA games.  this game glorifies that.  it makes sense because it's the WWE.  it doesn't translate to a fun video game however.  i want to play the game, not sift through menus.then we get to the "pagentry" of the WWE.  this game tries to show all of it.  are you familiar with the press conferences in NBA 2K?  know how you wish you could just skip that and get to the next game?  in WWE you must go out of your way to speak to the crowd, or your character's stats will suffer.  every guy has an entrance.  all the stuff you normally press start to skip in NBA just takes four times as long here.  i want to play the game, not look at how pretty the lights are when some guy comes walking towards the ring.the fights are varied, which is definitely a positive compared to MMA games.  there are 4 way brawls, 3 on 3, 2 on 2, and others.  this definitely helps during the course of a long career.  the game isn't horrible by any means.  as stated it runs perfectly on my comp.  the controls are tight, for what they are.  graphics are great but nowadays i can't ever complain about that.  however once you've dealt with all the menus, light shows, talking trash at other wrestlers and actually get into a match it just isn't fun to play.

Fast-forward to 2k17 and not a lot has changed, which is good, but I'll explain why this version is even better for me. First off, I highly recommend the game if you like wrestling games. It's one of my favorites of all time, but if you didn't like 2k16 for whatever reason, you probably won't like 2k17, but it depends. CAW, which is my favorite feature in any wrestling game, is better in most ways in 2k17 than it has ever been.I 've created about 30 wrestlers so far, so I've used it extensively. They've added a lot to every catagory (hair styles, clothes, teeth, etc...) but one HUGE disappoint for me is that you still cannot create little people. I would love to create a much shorter wrestler, but the shortest you can go is only 5'6", which continues to bum me out year after year. How hard would it be to extend the range of heights to under 5 foot??? I want to make a dwarf dammit! Aside from that, you pick from body types and pre-made parts (arms, legs, chest, etc...) instead of using a body slider. This is a step back as it doesn't let me have the customization we once had. Gone are the days of making an incredibly huge breasted thin woman. Not that I create that type of CAW or anything...other than that, the CAW has improved in every possible way=more of everything! It still irratates me that Yukes always does this year after year. Adds something, takes away. No create-a-finisher either, in this version, but next year they'll tout it as a "brand new never before seen feature!!!" Love/hate relationship when it comes to Yukes.The graphics are a bit better, but some wrestlers actually look like♥♥♥♥♥♥compared to others. Not a big deal to me because I usually just use my CAWs, but you can tell some wrestlers got a little more tlc than others. Audio is pretty much poop as  Diddy's song selection is downright "weird" for a wrestling video game, but again, no issue, as I turn on most every wrestler's entrace as my menu music (jukebox). The commentary has been recycled for the last 5 years but it doesn't really bother me much, I'm more in this game for the actual gameplay.The gameplay is about the same as 2k16, but with slight improvments! A 2nd opportunity to reverse on certain moves, the option to change the god-awful submission system to more of a classic button mashing submission system, and the "Break Out" feature after the match, which allows you to further pummel a wrestler you have already beaten. I LOVE these new features. ! The game pace is still more geared towards simulation, so expect slower pacing, not blazing fast arcade pacing. Although you can change some options, and that gets us to my final point...If you don't like the game and you think it's utter ****, for the love of all that is holy and sacred in this world, CHANGE THE SETTINGS!!!! and change the balancing!!!!! I cannot emphasize this enough!!! I really did not enjoy this game that much until I changed some settings. The pacing was too slow and the time the wrestlers were stunned was way too long, which made for a very boring match! After tweaking the balance, I'm good to go, and now have a bit faster paced matches. That may not be your cup of tea, but there is plenty of settings you can change to make the match more fun for you, whatever that may be. Guys/gals, seriously, I've been playing wrestling games since NES, the settings in these Yukes titles can make a big difference.  In closing wwe 2k17 is the best we have yet on PC just don't go in expecting a No Mercy as everyone seems to do, every friggin year...ugh...in ways it's better than No Mercy,, the CAW feature alone will keep you entertained. As far as issues with crashes, rare, in my playtime only 3 times so far and it was during load, not during the middle of anything, so I never lost any data. Runs smooth maxed 60fps 24/7 on my system.***I do not play any wrestling games online mode after atrocious matches I tried to have in a much earlier version, I believe it was wwe 10 or something, spamming the same move was the name of the game. Know going in that online in any wrestling game is a low priority and it should never be bought for that, it usually does not work well at all with many people picking a wrestler who is fast and can pull off the same exact fast move, over and over, so I could care less about MP in a wrestling game

												It feels a bit sparse, and in my eyes it doesn't quite compare to some of the earlier games in the series. It's as though more effort went into the earlier games. I haven't played many of the WWE games in years, in fact the last one I actually owned was WWE SvR 2009. Therefore with an 8 year gap between games, the difference in quality is striking, whether this is due to the series being taken over by 2K or just a general lack of creativity among the creators. It feels very uninspired and unfinished. I understand that these guys are expected to put out a new game every year, but still.The graphics are better than 2009 etc, but that's to be expected and not something that I focus on much. It does make my PC lag pretty badly, but with a crappy little box like mine, that's more my fault than theirs.The MyCareer mode feels outright repetitive with the illusion of challenges thrown in to try and spice up the repetitive slog of match after match after match. It also bugs me that you go straight from the training facility to WWE RAW. In my second week I was put up against Brock Lesnar. There's no sense of build-up, aside from the paper-thin Championship rankings, etc. I get that this is how it's been for years now, but in previous years the Career mode had actual storylines with rivalries and choice-based branching paths. This version doesn't even have voice acting besides the commentators, the ringside announcers, and A-Train near the start. This is how it was in WWE 2005, 12 years ago! And even then, WWE 2005 had actual storylines. It feels like 2K decided to focus more on implementing larger rosters and sharp, fluid gameplay rather than making things actually entertaining.It's very jarring to have your match interrupted with an Instant Replay whenever you do something big. It's a great example of putting realism before player enjoyment. I just did the move! I know how it works! I don't need to have the pace of the match brought to a screeching halt to see it 3 more times. Save it for the post-match highlights if you need to put it somewhere. I know I can skip it, but it still throws me off, because *it doesn't happen every time you do your finisher*. You can't be prepared for it! At least you can choose to turn settings like these off.The AI is choppy at times. Every now and again you'll get thrown to the floor and your opponent will instead step out onto the apron and throw punches at thin air. Or else your teammates/opponents will get out of te ring and not try to climb back in before the 10-count. I won't mention the glitches though. Those have been around for ages and they're not getting fixed any time soon. One thing though - and I'm not sure if I messed up or if something's actually wrong, but in MyCareer mode, my created superstar's entrance music doesn't play despite me making 110% sure that it does. The post-match music works perfectly though. What gives?Also - and this is something I've seen tons of other people complain about - the game keeps crashing! I have to constantly hold thumbs that the game won't conk out when I'm in the middle of doing something important. Yesterday I spent 20+ minutes tweaking my created superstar's moveset when the game crashed out of nowhere and I lost all my progress. Seriously, there's like a 50% chance that if I try to edit my character it'll crash. And then I need to wait 5 minutes for the damn thing to boot up again (if I don't give up and play something else for a while) and run the risk of it just crashing again. The PC version has been out for nearly two months! Surely this is something that could (and should) have been fixed early on? I'd be so much happier if I could just play the damn thing. Please just fix the crashing issue and I can deal with the rest. Are we just on our own from now on? This stuff is game-breaking. People are spending serious money on a game that only works when it feels like it.It also bugs me that I can't skip cutscenes. I'm so sick of watching the RAW and SmackDown intro sequences.I do like how they can read out my full name though :P "From Cape Town, South Africa... Adam McKay!" I never get tired of that. I also like the roster, with the potential to buy a ton of bonus superstars (and for in-game currency too, thank god!)As I mentioned before, this game feels unfinished, making me wonder if I should have bought one of the earlier games instead. Considering that you don't really get your money's worth, I probably wouldn't recommend it to a friend. There's just so much missing from previous years that were awesome! Finisher creators, Storyline creators, Career storylines, actual voice acting! I get that the game is already 40+ GB as it is, but making it seem less sparse would definitely make people enjoy it more. As it is, I feel silly for paying so much for something with not very much to offer. I feel as though I'm lumbered with it, rather than being the proud owner of my first WWE game in 8 years.It's not fun.

												WWE 2K17 improves upon the formula created back in 2K15, with new additions pushing the boundaries of the wrestling sim genre. While this is a positive for fans of the style, and of WWE's product, it may not be to everyone's liking.WWE 2K17 continues on from the previous two iterations of the game, further stepping away from the arcade style on display in earlier titles like the Smackdown VS Raw series. While this is not really news to most people, there will be still be some who decide to jump back into the world of WWE games through this release. 2K17 much like the previous two games, requires a more strategic approach, gone are infinite reversals and unlimited stamina. While I feel that this adds a lot of depth to the actual gameplay, it can put more casual players off.The gameplay itself is continually becoming more and more refined with each year, the animations are smooth, the bumps look real. The new taunt systems helps add more realism to each match, allowing taunts to be aimed at the crowd, and letting wrestlers climb on the turnbuckle to stand triumphant, the submission mini-game and pin system remain the same from the previous two games, but are still strong and balanced enough that it's not much of a problem. Multi-man matches are much better in 2K17 in comparison to pretty much all of the other WWE titles, instead of being a cluttered mess, this time around, once taking a substantial amount of damage, much like on TV, superstars will roll out of the ring and remain outside in order to rest, before climbing back in to resume the brawl. This does help to immerse you in the experience, and helps make multi-superstar matches much cleaner, and more enjoyable. However, there is still a limit of only six superstars at one time, which I would like to see changed, but you can understand why the limit is in place, considering the limited resources that consoles have, given that this is a port. One major negative point about this game is that, much like all other WWE 2K titles, it is rife with bugs. Be it glitches in matches, or the game crashing altogether (Which has happened pretty frequently with me, only while running in fullscreen though.) The only positive thing i have to say about ths is that the black ring glitch from 2K16 seems to have been fixed as I have not experienced it at all with this title.Career mode is a definite improvement over 2k16's as the roster feels more alive this time around. In the previous iteration, the career mode worked like this. If you were face, Seth Rollins was WWE champion, If you were heel, Brock Lesnar held the gold. This time, it feels more alive, as I have seen titles change at Pay Per Views etc. Imagine the career mode as a modified universe mode to a degree. One of the most significant changes in the career mode is that 2K have tried to make their product feel like a genuine WWE show. Before each show the intro video for the show plays (Be it Smackdown, Raw, NXT, Superstars, Main Event.) and you watch the pyro on the main stage etc. The novelty wears off after a while, but it does help to immerse you in the experience.The character creation is still great, with more new content than 2K16, nothing much more to really talk about regarding this. It's pretty good!No showcase mode in the base game, they are adding it via DLC, which personally doesn't bother me, there is enough content in the game to make it worthwhile without the showcase mode. A quick side note, this is the first WWE PC title to  include the paid DLC. Previously all DLC was lumped in with the game, while I've not purchased any yet, and am still unsure if I will or not, there is enough content in the vanilla game without having to purchase any extra DLC. Plus, the online creations are still available for free, so you can always just download any missing superstars. One final thing to mention, this game was in development long before the whole brand split stuff that happened on TV, as a result it was already outdated from the moment it launched unfortunately, you can fix this in universe mode through downloading custom arenas etc.So, Should you buy WWE2K17? Yes, I think so. It's a solid addition to the WWE 2K Franchise, while not being particularly groundbreaking, it does solidify on a lot of the changes made in 2K16, while adding some spice of its own.PLUS IT FINALLY HAS AJ STYLES.

												So the last rasslin' game I played was WWE 2k15, and this is an immense improvement over that.  I played a lot of PS1/2/3/4 rasslin games too, and I think with 2k17 they are finally getting back to the expectations that those titles from many years ago set for me.THE GOOD:- all the mini-games are great, I'm a big fan of the submission system.  They're not too complicated but they feel skillfull and thankfully there's no button mashing.  No more being at the mercy of simple dice rolls to determine the outcome of the match, now I can get good at stuff and feel like I actually won or lost.  It makes the whole thing feel more gamey.- character abilities so far have led a very satisfying air of strategy to matches.  It's nothing too complex, but I do find myself using strategies to get 5 star matches while avoiding a loss.  This whole part feels a bit more fleshed out and better thought out than it did in 2k15.- the game is a lot more clear about how to get 5 star matches, and it lets you know how well you're doing on that during the match.  This goes hand in hand with my previous comment because it really shapes my choices during the match.  If I'm on the verge of getting five stars I might pull some risky stuff for a great match and try to be clever with the use of my wrestler's abilities to mitigate the risk.  Sometimes it backfires on me and I have to adjust to a losing situation - have had some very exciting match endings because of this!- character creater has so many options it's silly.  In fact, some of the things you can put on your character are kind of silly.  Everything looks great too - I've basically made the same guy in every rasslin' game I ever played, but this time around he looks the coolest!  In fact, he looks more like an actual guy than some of the actual wrestlers in the game do - first time I've seen created wrestlers look more high def than the real guys lol- Career mode is hugely improved.  Things started kicking off immediately - a few matches in I was slowly on my way to a title, and part of a rivalry.  Lots of little interactions happen in between of matches as well, and overall you get a lot more options to interact with your career.  Compared to the nothing that was the 2k15 career mode, this is pretty fantastic and was the one part of the game where I really wanted to see some improvement.THE OKAY- I'm a bit half and half on the reversal system.  It feels like having more reversals than your opponent is just such a hard numerical advantage because once he's done reversing, you still can.  End result: you are in charge of the match every time an exchanges of reversals end. I would have liked to see some more mechanics that allow you to get reversals back to sort of break this pattern.  Certain reversals being able to lockout your opponents reversals temporarily is a start - but again, works better for the wrestler who has more reversals.- the promo system, where your character walks out to the ring and flaps their jaw, or gets into some verbal sparring with another wrestler is on the one hand a really exciting mechanic for the game.  However, the choices feel really cryptic like the little chunk of preview text you choose doesn't always let you know what your character is really going to say.  The fact that you have to match up both your general tone on various subjects along with a face/heel image in order to get a strong reaction out of the current type of crowd means those choices need to be pretty clear.  I pick something that I think is gonna be a nice friendly face comment for a family friendly crowd, and next thing you know I'm being a huge heel.THE BAD- character creater doesn't have body morphing sliders ( or if there are any I haven't found them ) which reduces the ability to really fine tune your created wrestlers.- I have pretty decent hardware and I had to fiddle with graphics settings to get the game running smoothly.  I still basically have graphics settings maxed though, so everything looks fantastic.  Overall it runs great though - feels generalyl more responsive than 2k15.

												As someone who's played nearly all the WWE games since 2002's "Shut Your Mouth", I can say that this is definitely one of the better games of the series, and definitely a step up from 2K's other wrestling endeavours.To begin, I get very few performance issues on any game I play, so that means 2K17 is no different. In 25 hours of play, the game has crashed once, and I occasionally get some FPS stutter, but other than that, and the other random glitches you get in a 2K wrestling game, I didn't have any issues in that department.Ever since I started playing wrestling games, I've always played them for the story mode. In Shut Your Mouth and Here Comes the Pain, it was the brilliant Season mode, in 2011 it was the Road to Wrestlemanias, and in 2K's next-gen videogames, it's MyCareer, their vision for the player to be able to recreate what it's like for a WWE superstar to rise up from humble beginnings and become a main eventer, all while relatively keeping kayfabe in check. MyCareer has, for the most part, been nearly exclusively what I've played in 2K's games. In 2015, it was a barebones excuse of a broken system that occasionally produced interesting feuds every ten hours. In 2016, it fixed many of those problems, although these "fixes" included 8 redudant matches followed by 1 semi-important match to a feud that was destined to go nowhere, along with title systems that didn't work. In 2K17, these problems are fixed. Not only do you have variety in how feuds start, end, and their length, but you can now challenge for titles much earlier, have much more control over what happens, and a re-balancing of attributes and difficulty makes these matches a genuine challenge while still being close enough and interesting enough to be riveting. You feel a genuine character progression with your CAW, through promos, championship wins, and where his spot on the card happens to land every week. Now, only occasionally do the eight matches between PPVs feel tedious, unlike 2K16, where they almost always did. My primary complaints lie in the fact that the customization suite doesn't seem to be as detailed as last years, at least for CAWs. Overall, though, there does seem to be more content within the game, including an absolutely massive roster and many different arenas. With that being said, DLC that was free last year will cost you $30 this year, as will some basic features that were available last year. The only reason I can look over this is because I think all the other items in the Season Pass are definitely worth $30, and as an avid fan of WWE, I'm willing to pay that much money for the product. Considering that it was FREE last year, however, does make me slightly sour.Considering all my experiences I've had in the 25 hours I've played so far, I'd recommend a buy. 												Is this game a good game? Well kind of, but it falls short in many small ways but it hits the big notes pretty well. On certain in game models this game looks amazing, some wrestlers *cough* Dana Brooke *cough* it's absolutely terrifying. The charcter creation is back in a big way especially compared to how 2K started their tenure with this series, plenty of options to choose from even borrowing gear from real life WWE talent that you can fully customize. You can get lost for hours just making one CAW, so that alone is worth the price of admission for a life long wrestling game fan like me. And that's not to say that the other creation modes are bad, because most of them are pretty good. Arena is amazing, giving you plenty of options to make a unique arena that you can use in Universe Mode. Creating titles is pretty fun, if at times a little annoying because some logos don't fit. The biggest dissapointments as far as the creation system goes is create a video and creat a victory. Create a Victory should really be called choose which WWE star you are going to copy when you win. Create a video is good so long as you are only making entrance videos, don't think about using the other scenes. Making a video using in ring actions, like Staredowns or Brawls, is a war of attrition and actions of faith. What may look good in the preview, will come out like steam pressed poop after encoding. Universe Mode is still better than Career Mode for those of you wanting to make your creation the baddest superstar, EVAH. Career Mode is better, but it still takes forever to even get a title shot. The promo engine is a step in the right direction, but it desperately needs VO (please just grab some indy guys and let them do some VO work for next years edition.) And yeah the Heyman challenge and the Authority stuff is kinda cool, but not for long and it becomes more of a chore than a pleasure later in the game. Overall would I recommend this game, if you are a wrestling fan yes. Liking this game is akin to being a wrestling fan in real life, you know it's bad but you can't help but fall in love with it's imperfections.
